column4: then i suggest that you have a look around and find the real .core file ;)
what is this file "BST?"
it's an executable that I compiled to implement a binary search tree
and when you actually execute it ... ?
it seg faults and core dumps
so I want to use gdb to debug it
well, the executable itself is not a .core logfile of the dump.
sudo updatedb && locate .core
it put the core file in the folder that I executed from, and it is called "core"
run gdb against that file
just that file?: gdb core?
gdb requires an executable
sure, unless you need to add arguments
no, no arguments
this is the web page I was looking at, where I got the idea: http://www.cprogramming.com/debugging/segfaults.html
I ran gdp -c ./core and it still said "./core is not a core dump: File format not recognized"
er, gdb - not gdp
I ran 'sudo updatedb && locate .core' and it didn't find a core file
then you need to figure out where the .core files are getting placed when your app segfaults.
to get the core file to appear in the first place, I had to run 'ulimit -c unlimited', so I'm pretty confident that is the core file
you may find that the IRC channel(s), web forums, mailing lists (or whatever) for that piece of code are of more help.
and it reappears if I delete it and run my program again
then it is not in a format gdb expects
okay
